@agneevX Thatâ€™s fair; they do a lot of odd things when it comes to featuring. 

I think itâ€™s a bit of an Apples /Organges comparison though. Apple would have to sniff the network, consolidate a list of all potential websites that involve tracking, understand how the data is used, etc.

@agneevX With that said, Apple defines â€œtrackingâ€ very specifically and itâ€™s more specific than the average userâ€™s definition. 

In this instance, Iâ€™m not sure using Branch violates any terms other than not listing it in the privacy section.

@agneevX Overall, I agree with the sentiment though. The Privacy section is completely self submitted and therefore bad actors arenâ€™t going to fill it out accurately. Itâ€™s also pretty confusing to fill out since the language to do so is fairly verbose and easy to misunderstand.
@randomnessncats @agneevX @AppleSupport With that said, they should list data collection in the Privacy section and that the collection isnâ€™t used for tracking (based on Appleâ€™s definition).

@randomnessncats @agneevX @AppleSupport Branch (the SDK in question) may be a data broker (not positive). They mainly do mobile attribution so you can attribute where users are coming from.

@randomnessncats @agneevX @AppleSupport Iâ€™m not sure this is me necessarily true. They define tracking as related to ads, linking users from 3rd parties, and data brokers.

@ChristianSelig @mdufort @teddumitrescu Yeah, I definitely feel the same. For my personal apps, I'm in the same boat. I'm only using Firebase for my own apps and I'm equally annoyed how hard it is to visualize the data. If you find a better "indie" solution that fits all your needs, I'd love to hear an update.

@ChristianSelig @mdufort @teddumitrescu That also allows us to look "down funnel." One variant may have higher conversion but might cause worse retention, for example. So, it's not always enough to know that a paywall/signup converts better, but that other things (such as retention) aren't negatively affected.

@ChristianSelig @mdufort @teddumitrescu RevenueCat, for example, has its own A/B testing where it buckets users. We forward what variants users are in through to our own analytics, so it's all in one place.

@ChristianSelig @mdufort @teddumitrescu Yeah, totally fair. This stuff can be confusing, so just wanted to clarify. 

Unfortunately, the less expensive options specialize. So they don't have both A/B testing and great analytics analysis. However, for the most basics, Firebase can do it all, if you use GA console.

@ChristianSelig @mdufort @teddumitrescu This is what I was referring to by combining Firebase + Analytics tool.

Firebase creates what users are in a variant of a test. App sends the analytics tool (Amplitude, Mixpanel, etc) what a/b test these users are in via â€œuser propertiesâ€ and use analytics tool for measurement.

@ChristianSelig @teddumitrescu @NathanBLawrence Itâ€™s not necessarily ideal if you want 1 tool for everything, but you can use Firebase a/b testing and then forward what variant users are in to your analytics tool (TelemetryDeck, for example) for deeper analysis.

I do this with Firebase + Amplitude right now.

@chrisvasselli @ChristianSelig Yah, I believe thatâ€™s right. Itâ€™s using uniques, not totals. As long as you set the right activation event & right conversion event, youâ€™re good. I believe firebase will also give a confidence or statistical significance in terms of how confident one variant is vs another.
@EthanLipnik Youâ€™re amazing. Canâ€™t wait to see where you go from here. All my achievements were well past 19. ğŸ™Œ
@Cyclebrity Me too. ğŸ˜ƒ

@ChristianSelig Ultimately it depends on your needs and how deep you want to go on understanding user actions, optimizing funnels, a/b tests, etc.

I think Amplitude has a free tier if you just wanted to try out the dashboard. TelemtryDeck seems nice, but I couldnâ€™t find a demo for comparison.

@ChristianSelig @NathanBLawrence If youâ€™re serious about an alternative analytics solution, Iâ€™d recommend at least inquiring about the price since the tool is really good, but may also be more than you need; it really depends what youâ€™re missing from current analytics and what type analysis youâ€™d like to see.

@emoryzanef @ChristianSelig I donâ€™t think any scaled company is using Firebase for their analytics. We use Amplitude and previously Mixpanel. Both of which are infinitely better, but also not free. Firebase is good for the most basic stuff, but that great or intuitive for any complex analysis.
@NathanBLawrence @ChristianSelig Yes. If youâ€™re going to use FireBase for analytics, itâ€™s basically a requirement to use Data Studio to really see the data.

@kovacsamate @levelsio I think the question becomes, how many years would it take the buyer to recoup their money and make a profit? 

Most will want a payback period of 2-4 years. So figure out what your growth rate is and what the multiple would need to be to reach 2-4 year payback period.

@kovacsamate @levelsio Thereâ€™s too many factors. It depends on the type of business, growth, company thatâ€™s buying it, etc.

Mine sold for 15x annual revenue (not ARR), but thatâ€™s because I didnâ€™t really want to sell it and the revenue wasnâ€™t that much; the buyer just really wanted it.
